xxl.core.cursors.mappers
Class Aggregator<E,A>

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor<A>
      xxl.core.cursors.mappers.Aggregator<E,A>
Type Parameters:
E - the type of the elements returned by the iteration to be aggregated.
A - the type of the elements returned by the aggregated iteration.
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.util.Iterator<A>, Cursor<A>
Direct Known Subclasses:
Aggregator, GroupAggregator, GroupAggregator, Minimator, RectangleUniverseDouble, ReservoirSampler, UniverseDouble, UniverseFloat
public class Aggregator<E,A>
extends AbstractCursor<A>

The aggregator incrementally computes one or even more aggregates for an input iteration. Due to the fact that an aggregator has to be initialized, the user defined aggregation-function has to handle the case that the aggregate is null. If the initialization of the aggregate is finished, in the next step the aggregate-function is applied on the aggregate and the input iteration's (a given input iterator is internally wrapped to a cursor} peek-element, i.e., the element returned by the iteration's peek method. In order to indicate that the aggregation-function has not yet become initialized, null is returned. The following code fragment shows this behaviour: 

     aggregate = function.invoke(aggregate, input.peek());
     if (aggregate != null)
         initialized = true;
     return aggregate;
If the aggregate has been initialized, the further computation is demand-driven, so a call to the next method will set the aggregate as follows: 
     aggregate = function.invoke(aggregate, input.next());
This incremental computation with the help of a binary aggregation-function implies that the absolute aggregate's value is first being determined when the last element of the underlying iteration has been consumed and the aggregation function has been applied. If the user is not interested in the incremental computation of the aggregate during the demand-driven computation, the final aggregation value can be delivered directly calling the method last.

Futhermore the aggregator offers the possibility to define more than one binary aggregation function, i.e., the user is able to compute a sum and an average of the same data set in only one iteration process. This kind of usage is often needed for SQL queries on relations. For further information concerning the usage of multi-aggregate functions see Aggregator. Another very impressive use of this class is given by the reservoir-sampler which uses a reservoir sampling function with a given strategy for on-line sampling.

Note: When the given input iteration only implements the interface Iterator it is wrapped to a cursor by a call to the static method wrap.

Example usage: 

     Aggregator<Integer, Integer> aggregator = new Aggregator<Integer, Integer>(
         new DiscreteRandomNumber(new JavaDiscreteRandomWrapper(100), 50),
         new AggregationFunction<Integer, Integer>() {
             public Integer invoke(Integer aggregate, Integer next) {
                 if (aggregate == null)
                     return next;
                 return aggregate = Math.max(aggregate, next);
             }
         }
     );
 
     aggregator.open();
 
     System.out.print("The result of the maximum aggregation is: " + aggregator.last());
 
     aggregator.close();
This example determines the maximum of 50 random numbers with the restriction that the value of a random number is not greater than 99. A new function for the aggregation is defined that compares the value of the current aggregate with the value of the next object and returns the object with the maximum value. Furthermore the first two lines of the invoke method show the initialization of this instance of an aggregator. Because the aggregator works demand-driven the absolute maximum is definitively detected if all elements were consumed. Therefore the method last is used generating the final output. At last the aggregator is closed with the intention to release resources.

In order to compute various aggregation-functions simultanously, they must be wrapped by a special aggregation-function that calls successively all given functions. The wrapping aggregation-function is initialized if and only if all specified functions are initialized, meaning null will be returned by calling the next method as long as all functions will return objects that are not null! After initialization a list containing the aggregation values given by the corresponding functions will be returned every time calling the next method! 

   Aggregator<Integer, List<Integer>> aggregator2 = new Aggregator<Integer, List<Integer>>(
       new DiscreteRandomNumber(new JavaDiscreteRandomWrapper(100), 50), // the input cursor
       Maths.multiDimAggregateFunction(
           new AggregationFunction<Integer, Integer>() { // the aggregation function
               public Integer invoke(Integer aggregate, Integer next) {
                   if (aggregate == null)
                       return next;
                   return Maths.max(aggregate, next);
               }
           },
           new AggregationFunction<Integer, Integer>() { // the second aggregation function
               public Integer invoke(Integer aggregate, Integer next) {
                   if (aggregate == null)
                       return next;
                   return aggregate + next;
               }
           }
       )
   );

Iterator, Cursor, AbstractCursor, Aggregator

Field Detail

input

protected Cursor<? extends E> input
The input iteration holding the data to be aggregated.

function

protected AggregationFunction<? super E,A> function
The function used for the aggregation. This binary function is invoked with the prior aggregate and the next element of the input iteration. When the aggregate is not yet initialized, a null value is given to the aggregation-function.

aggregate

protected A aggregate
The current aggregate of the processed input iteration.

initialized

protected boolean initialized
A boolean flag to detect if an result-object for the aggregation has been specified, i.e., the aggregate is already initialized.

Constructor Detail

Aggregator

public Aggregator(java.util.Iterator<? extends E> iterator,
                  AggregationFunction<? super E,A> function)
Creates a new aggregator backed on an input iteration and an aggregation function. Every iterator given to this constructor is wrapped to a cursor.

Parameters:
iterator - the input iteration holding the data to be aggragated.
function - an aggregation-function.
Method Detail

open

public void open()
Opens the aggregator, i.e., signals the cursor to reserve resources, open the input iteration, etc. Before a cursor has been opened calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Therefore open must be called before a cursor's data can be processed. Multiple calls to open do not have any effect, i.e., if open was called the cursor remains in the state opened until its close method is called.

Note, that a call to the open method of a closed cursor usually does not open it again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

Specified by:
open in interface Cursor<A>
Overrides:
open in class AbstractCursor<A>

close

public void close()
Closes the aggregator, i.e., signals the cursor to clean up resources, close the input iterations, etc. When a cursor has been closed calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Multiple calls to close do not have any effect, i.e., if close was called the cursor remains in the state closed.

Note, that a closed cursor usually cannot be opened again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

Specified by:
close in interface Cursor<A>
Overrides:
close in class AbstractCursor<A>

hasNextObject

protected boolean hasNextObject()
Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)

Specified by:
hasNextObject in class AbstractCursor<A>
Returns:
true if the aggregator has more elements, otherwise false.

nextObject

protected A nextObject()
Returns the next element in the iteration. This element will be accessible by some of the aggregator's methods, e.g., update or remove, until a call to next or peek occurs. This is calling next or peek proceeds the iteration and therefore its previous element will not be accessible any more.

Specified by:
nextObject in class AbstractCursor<A>
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.

last

public A last()
       throws java.util.NoSuchElementException
Returns the last element of this aggregator. This element represents the final aggregation value.

Returns:
the last element of the aggregator.
Throws:
java.util.NoSuchElementException - if a last element does not exist, i.e., the input iteration does not hold enough elements to initialize the aggregate.

reset

public void reset()
           throws java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
Resets the aggregator to its initial state such that the caller is able to traverse the aggregation again without constructing a new aggregator (optional operation).

Note, that this operation is optional and might not work for all cursors.

Specified by:
reset in interface Cursor<A>
Overrides:
reset in class AbstractCursor<A>
Throws:
java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset operation is not supported by the aggregator.

supportsReset

public boolean supportsReset()
Returns true if the reset operation is supported by the aggregator. Otherwise it returns false.

Specified by:
supportsReset in interface Cursor<A>
Overrides:
supportsReset in class AbstractCursor<A>
Returns:
true if the reset operation is supported by the aggregator, otherwise false.
